facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 525 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 525 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 360 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 360 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 360 of 1961. 76 5 S. Bobde G. L. Sanghi and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant is the Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola and the respondents two of the workmen of the Mills. The respondents are claiming from the Mills companypensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960.

facts.text: Respondents are two workmen of the Mills.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondents two of the workmen of the Mills. The respondents are claiming from the Mills companypensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960. The proceedings were companymenced by an application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947 .

facts.text: Respondents claimed compensation for lay-off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are claiming from the Mills companypensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960. The proceedings were companymenced by an application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947 . The Mills objected on various grounds including firstly that the Second Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to hear the case as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947

facts.text: Proceedings commenced by application to Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C(1) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings were companymenced by an application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947 . The Mills objected on various grounds including firstly that the Second Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to hear the case as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947 and, secondly, that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent.

facts.text: Mills objected that Second Labour Court lacked jurisdiction as dispute to be tried under C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills objected on various grounds including firstly that the Second Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to hear the case as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947 and, secondly, that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent. The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds.

facts.text: Mills objected that application under s. 33C was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: and, secondly, that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent. The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds. The Mills applied to the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution but by the judgment under appeal their application was dismissed.

facts.text: Second Labour Court held against Mills on both grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds. The Mills applied to the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution but by the judgment under appeal their application was dismissed. It may be pointed out here that there were similar applications for company- pensation for lay off by the other workmen of the Mills and on this preliminary point they were all heard together.

facts.text: Mills applied to Bombay High Court under Articles 226 and 227, application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills applied to the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution but by the judgment under appeal their application was dismissed. It may be pointed out here that there were similar applications for company- pensation for lay off by the other workmen of the Mills and on this preliminary point they were all heard together. In this Court only these two grounds were urged.

facts.text: Similar applications for lay-off compensation by other workmen of the Mills, heard together on preliminary point.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out here that there were similar applications for company- pensation for lay off by the other workmen of the Mills and on this preliminary point they were all heard together. In this Court only these two grounds were urged. The company- tention on behalf of the Mills on the first ground was two- fold.

facts.text: In Supreme Court, only two grounds urged by Mills.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court only these two grounds were urged. The company- tention on behalf of the Mills on the first ground was two- fold. The Mills attempted to establish that the dispute companyld number be tried under the Central Act but only under the P. Berar Act

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 passed in 1947, brought into force on April 1, 1947, applied to Textile Industry.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Disputes Act was passed in 1947 and was brought into force on April 1, 1947. It is number disputed that it applied to the Textile Industry. The C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947 but only the first section was then brought into force.

facts.text: C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 23 of 1947 came into force on June 2, 1947 for first section.

anchor.surface_text: The C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947 but only the first section was then brought into force. Later, the remaining sections were brought into force by a numberification dated November 20, 1947 in all industries except the Textile Industry.

facts.text: Remaining sections of C.P. Berar Act brought into force on November 20, 1947 except Textile Industry.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the remaining sections were brought into force by a numberification dated November 20, 1947 in all industries except the Textile Industry. From March 1, 1951, the Act was also, 76 6 made applicable to the Textile industry. In 1953 the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was amended by Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act, 1953.

facts.text: C.P. Berar Act made applicable to Textile Industry from March 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: From March 1, 1951, the Act was also, 76 6 made applicable to the Textile industry. In 1953 the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was amended by Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act, 1953. The changes material to our purpose were the addition of two definitions and a new chapter in the Act.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 amended in 1953 adding definitions of lay-off and retrenchment, and Chapter V-A.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953 the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was amended by Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act, 1953. The changes material to our purpose were the addition of two definitions and a new chapter in the Act. Previous to the Act there was an Ordinance which the Act replaced but as numberhing turns upon the existence of the Ordinance we need number refer to it.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act amended in 1956 adding section 33C.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956 the Industrial Disputes Act was again amended by the Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1956. Section 23 of the Amending Act inserted section 33C which reads as follows 33-C. Recovery of money due from an employer.-

facts.text: Powers of Government under section 33C delegated to Second Labour Court, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The -powers of the Government under the above section admittedly have been delegated to the Second Labour Court Bombay. Section 31 of this Amending Act provides as follows Act number to override State laws.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected Mills' contention that C.P. Berar Act applies instead of Industrial Disputes Act for lay-off compensation.

Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act does. ... The attempt to keep out the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act, particularly Chapter V-A and s. 33C must, therefore, fail.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that lay-off compensation determined under Chapter V-A of Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.text: compensation for lay off can only be determined under Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: sions indisputably arise. The first conclusion is that compensation for lay off can only be determined under Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act. This follows from s. 25J 2  as it is so stated there. The next is that the workmen are entitled under s. 33C 1  to go before the Second Labour Court to realise money due from their employers under Chapter V-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly stated in s.25J(2) that rights and liabilities relating to lay-off shall be determined under Chapter V-A notwithstanding inconsistent laws.

holdings.text: the workmen are entitled under s. 33C 1  to go before the Second Labour Court to realise money due from their employers under Chapter V-A

anchor.surface_text: The next is that the workmen are entitled under s. 33C 1  to go before the Second Labour Court to realise money due from their employers under Chapter V-A. This is clearly stated in s. 33C. The contention on behalf of the Mills, however, is that the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 does number apply to the present matter but the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act does.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33C(1) expressly provides for application to appropriate Government (delegated to Labour Court) for recovery of money due under Chapter V-A.

holdings.text: Section 31 can have no application because s. 33C has been included for the purpose, among others, of enabling the workmen to claim any money due from their employers under the provisions of Chapter V-A

This is expressly so stated in that section. Chapter V-A is the only Chapter in which there is provision regarding lay off or compensation for lay off.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of s.33C is to enable recovery under Chapter V-A; s.31 relates to settlement/adjudication of disputes generally, not specific rights under Chapter V-A.

holdings.text: Chapter V-A is the only Chapter in which there is provision regarding lay off or compensation for lay off. The C.P. Berar Act contains no provision either for the recovery of money or for compensation for lay off

anchor.surface_text: Chapter V-A is the only Chapter in which there is provision regarding lay off or compensation for lay off. The C.P. Berar Act contains no provision either for the recovery of money or for compensation for lay off. It is thus obvious that if a workman has a claim for lay off it can only come up for decision under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of provisions in C.P. Berar Act for lay-off compensation or recovery, unlike Chapter V-A.

holdings.text: even if ss. 31 and 25J save the application of the C.P. Berar Act they do so subject to the condition that question of lay off must be decided in accordance with Chapter V-A and S. 33C clearly provides that a dispute for any money due under Chapter V-A

Berar Act they do so subject to the condition that question of lay off must be decided in accordance with Chapter V-A and S. 33C clearly provides that a dispute for any money due under Chapter V-A has to go before the appropriate Government or its delegate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Savings clauses in ss.31 and 25J(1) are subject to s.25J(2) mandating Chapter V-A for lay-off and s.33C for recovery thereunder.

holdings.text: The argument that this controversy is wrongly before the Second Labour Court, Bombay is, therefore, entirely erroneous and must be rejected

anchor.surface_text: Here the delegate is the Second Labour Court, Bombay. The argument that this controversy is wrongly before the Second Labour Court, Bombay is, therefore, entirely erroneous and must be rejected. The next contention is that the claim for lay off is number a claim for money due because calculations have to be made before the money due can be found.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction confirmed as powers under s.33C delegated to Second Labour Court; C.P. Berar Act inapplicable to lay-off claims.

holdings.text: It is not essential that the claim which can be brought before the Government or its delegate under S. 33C 1 must always be for a predetermined sum. The Government or the Labour Court may satisfy itself about the exact amount and then take action under that section

anchor.surface_text: This argument has been considered on more than one occasion and it was rejected recently by this Court in Kays Construction Co.  P  Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors 1 . It is not essential that the claim which can be brought before the Government or its delegate under S. 33C 1  must always be for a predetermined sum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Kays Construction rejects need for predetermined sum; Labour Court can compute via simple arithmetic from records like muster rolls.

holdings.text: in the present case ... it will then be a simple arithmetical calculation which, in our judgment, s. 33C permits to be made

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the dates of lay off are known and each workmen will show to the Second Labour Court that he is qualified to receive compensation for lay off. That will be shown from the muster roll which the employer is required to maintain and it will then be a simple arithmetical calculation which, in our judgment, s. 33C permits to be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.33C(2) to compute money value of benefits, including lay-off compensation via muster rolls.

precedents.citation: Kays Construction Co. P Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors 1

anchor.surface_text: Kays Construction Co. P Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors 1 . It is number essential that the claim which can be brought before the Government or its delegate under S. 33C 1  must always be for a predetermined sum. The Government or the Labour Court may satisfy itself about the exact amount and then take action under that section. In the present case the dates of lay off are known and each workmen will show to the Second Labour Court that he is qualified to receive companypensation for 1. 1965 2 S.C.R. 276. up.C165-6 lay off.

precedents.case_name: Kays Construction Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: The claim under s. 33C(1) need not be for a predetermined sum; the Labour Court can determine and compute the exact amount due.
precedents.cited_holding: It is not essential that the claim which can be brought before the Government or its delegate under S. 33C(1) must always be for a predetermined sum.

Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 enables the High Court to render holdings on the applicability of specific provisions like Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act in jurisdictional disputes.

Article 226 of the Constitution provides High Court writ jurisdiction to adjudicate jurisdictional conflicts between central and state industrial laws, as reflected in clustering this issue under CONST_ART226.

anchor.surface_text: This argument has been considered on more than one occasion and it was rejected recently by this Court in Kays Construction Co.  P  Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors 1 .
